Award.AwardTitle: A Kinetic Model for Predicting Secondary Organic Aerosol Formation in Complex Hydrocarbon Mixtures
Award.AbstractNarration: Secondary organic aerosols (SOA) constitute the fine particulate matter fraction arising from the photochemical and oxidative processing of atmospheric hydrocarbons. Being able to predict SOA formation is a needed step forward to more accurate air-shed and air quality models, to predicting the health consequences of small aerosol particles and also their radiative impacts in climate models. This work will continue development of a semi-explicit kinetic model to predict SOA formation in complex mixtures of biogenic and anthropogenic hydrocarbons, ambient oxidants and also existing aerosols under specified atmospheric conditions, as studied in a smog chamber facility at University of North Carolina (Chapel Hill).

Background and Objective: The formation of organic aerosols in the atmosphere, often called secondary organic aerosols or SOA, result from atmospheric chemical reactions and can lead to a significant portion of the fine particle mass that urban populations breath. Since 1993 there have been a large number of studies that have shown that as atmospheric particle exposures increase, so do mortality and morbidity rates and these can result in significant societal costs. SOA can form from emissions of both man made organics (like aromatics in automotive exhaust) and emissions from trees and other vegetation. The goal of the research was to develop a predictive model for SOA formation. Ultimately these results could be used in larger airshed models so that the importance, with respect to SOA formation, of different organic emissions and their sources can be estimated.

Approach: In this study we used large outdoor chambers at the University of North Carolina’s outdoor chamber facility to investigate the SOA forming potential of aromatics which come from man-made mobile emission sources, and isoprene which comes from vegetative emissions. Experiments were done in the presence of an urban hydrocarbon environment, oxides of nitrogen, and natural sunlight.

To develop and exercise a new model, an experimental data base was needed that covers a wide range of conditions. Concentrations in the chamber were also selected so the amounts of aromatic SOA produced were in the range of what might be observed in urban atmospheres.  In response to recent work highlighting the importance of aerosol liquid water content on SOA formation from the oxidative products of organics, the relative humidity of the chamber and the type of initial seed aerosol present were varied to assess their impact on SOA formation. Two different types of initial chamber aerosols were used in combination with the urban hydrocarbon mixture and aromatics: ammonium sulfate, particles, and rural North Carolina background particles. Ammonium sulfate particles can comprise a significant portion of aerosols in the eastern part of the US and the water content of these aerosols can be easily estimated. Background aerosols are more complex, but in North Carolina are composed of ~25% by mass of ammonium sulfate.

Intellectual Merit: Some of the key findings of this research are:  1. We have begun to quantify the impact of particle phase water on SOA formation from aromatic and isoprene smog systems. Most important is that we observed that SOA was 3 to 5 time higher when experiments had relative humidities in the range 90% to 60%, compared to the same experiments that had relative humidities in the range of 5 to 20%. This is mainly due to particle phase water that accumulates in the inorganic particle phase.  Reactions of organic products that are soluble in this water phase lead to an enhanced buildup of SOA. This finding is very novel, since most of the previous work has been with dry seed systems and this phenomenon has been basically overlooked. In the process of this work we have developed an new condensed aromatic kinetic mechanism that predicts both gas oxide of nitrogen and ozone behavior, and particle phase SOA. 2. With respect to SOA formation for isoprene systems, the particle water effect is opposite that of aromatics.  Lower particle phase water seems to associate with more SOA.  We have also made advancements in developing a new isoprene gas kinetics model. 3.
